schema.name: mAdminState
schema.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
schema.label: Enable administrative state
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
A descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.name: UserSummary
AccessPolicies
schema.summary: Manage the set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Enter the set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile. When more than one policy applies to a resource, the most specific policy is used. To create access policies, enter a correctly formatted policy statement.</p><p>A policy statement takes the <tt><i>address</i> / <i>domain</i> / <i>resource</i> ?Access= <i>privileges</i> &amp; <i>field</i> = <i>value</i></tt> general format.</p><dl><dt><i>address</i></dt><dd>The complete local IP address or host alias. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any address.</dd><dt><i>domain</i></dt><dd>The complete name of the application domain. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any application domain.</dd><dt>resource</dt><dd>The complete value for the resource type. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any resource type.</dd><dt><i>privileges</i></dt><dd>The privileges to apply. Separate permissions with the plus sign (+). For example, <tt>a+d+x+r+w</tt> defines add, delete, execute, read, and write privileges.</dd><dt><i>field</i></dt><dd>The complete name of a specific property in the configuration; for example, <tt>Name</tt> .</dd><dt><i>value</i></dt><dd>The PCRE match expression for the property value; For example, <tt>foo(.*)bar</tt> .</dd></dl>
schema.description: <p>The set of access policies that define the access privileges for the profile. When more than one policy applies to a resource, the most specific policy is used. To create access policies, enter a correctly formatted policy statement.</p><p>A policy statement takes the <tt><i>address</i> / <i>domain</i> / <i>resource</i> ?Access= <i>privileges</i> &amp; <i>field</i> = <i>value</i></tt> general format.</p><dl><dt><i>address</i></dt><dd>The complete local IP address or host alias. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any address.</dd><dt><i>domain</i></dt><dd>The complete name of the application domain. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any application domain.</dd><dt>resource</dt><dd>The complete value for the resource type. Use an asterisk (*) to designate any resource type.</dd><dt><i>privileges</i></dt><dd>The privileges to apply. Separate permissions with the plus sign (+). For example, <tt>a+d+x+r+w</tt> defines add, delete, execute, read, and write privileges.</dd><dt><i>field</i></dt><dd>The complete name of a specific property in the configuration; for example, <tt>Name</tt> .</dd><dt><i>value</i></dt><dd>The PCRE match expression for the property value; For example, <tt>foo(.*)bar</tt> .</dd></dl>
